title: Thursday, 1st August 2019

11:18 am
BE11:18am

There were a few comments from Fed Chair Powell that either disappointed or confused markets overnight, which led to a stronger USD (DXY up 90bp), higher short-end US rates (2Y UST up 6bp) and lower equities (S&P lower by 1.1%). Some of these comments include “not the beginning of a long series of rate cuts,” it was intended to “insure against downside risks,” “we will use the tools that we have, a couple of rate hikes one way or the other isn’t going to matter so much if there is a downturn,” and that the rate cut was a “mid-cycle adjustment to policy.” However, Powell did provide some marginal relief to the risk-asset selloff in by highlighting (towards the end of his press conference) that he “didn’t say it’s just one” cut “or anything like that” and that “downside risks are really coming from abroad”.

Irish HF guy Retail car crash update : Intu Properties at £0.45p, 30p price target. Hammerson being dragged into mix even though they have France Premium outlets and Ireland.
GoliathNationalBank Need to move all of my GBP into more stable currencies like BTC and ETH
BE11:19am

Medium-term thoughts
From a medium-term perspective, we do not believe the overnight FOMC event necessarily changes the theme of the Fed, or for that matter global central banks easing.
Indeed, even though Powell did suggest that there was not going to be a prolonged easing cycle, the window for more cuts was still left open - though the Fed is likely to be more data/event dependent (such as US-China trade developments). In addition, with the Fed funds futures market repricing to now expecting 33bp of rate cuts by year end and a further 35bp of cuts by end 2020 (Figure 1), we believe this is not unreasonable. This is especially if Nomura Economics team’s less favourable macro outlook emerges including US growth slowing to a forecast 1.4% in Q4 19 (from 2.1% in Q2 19), US-China trade protectionism to worsen with US imposition of tariffs before year-end, and downside risks on China growth continuing. In addition, we believe the cycle of other global central bank easing/maintaining an ease bias is still intact and the ECB is likely to surprise the market on 12 September with a package of measures including a rate cut, interest rate tiering, and asset purchases.

Irish HF guy @Tom, performance fee of 15% of any excess NAV returns over a 10% cumulative hurdle rate per annum, no management fee. I guess it was his poster child for how good he saw himself being
YourGrannyOnBongos Surely you can't have "hikes one way or the other" - it's only a 'hike' if it's up
BE11:20am

Overall, our medium-term view of USD strength looks to remain intact, as the tug-o-war between global central bank monetary easing appears set to continue with risks skewed towards the ECB (at least relative to the Fed) surprising. Other potential supports to USD strength over the medium term include the US imposing tariffs on the EU, Brexit, and idiosyncratic European political risks. Lastly, we also believe that, if the US imposes tariffs on the remainder of its imports from China before year-end, RMB would depreciate sharply and lead to broad Asia/EM FX depreciation against USD.

BE11:27am

Mondi has reported H119 EBITDA of €894m (+5% yoy), which compares to our forecast of €886m. We note that performance was aided by a €39m yoy increase in the forestry fair value gain which predominantly benefitted Q219. Excluding maintenance impacts growth has moved from 10% in Q119 to +5% in Q219 (ex forestry fair value -5% decline in Q219). On the outlook, management notes that trading conditions were increasingly challenging through H119 and for the second half demand is generally softer across markets with prices for key paper grades currently below H1 levels. The dividend has been increased by 27%. We remain cautious on the sector.

BE11:28am

The key takeaways from the results are: (i) Kraft paper contracts without fixed pricing have seen price declines in Q219; (ii) Uncoated fine paper prices remain stable but management notes that hardwood pulp prices are down 6% sequentially in Q219 and this accelerated through the quarter; (iii) Forestry fair value gains increased by €39m yoy with management noting it will be significantly lower in H219; (iv) kraftliner and testliner prices are said to have stabilised with better order books in Q219; (v) the start-up of the kraft paper line in Steti has gone well and is contributing positively to performance.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

(If the ROTR could avoid casually libeling people by name that'd be super.)

BE11:29am

Jefferies:

BE11:29am

Solid 1H with EBITDA +5% to €894m (1H18: €852m) & EPS +8% to €0.96 in the
middle of pre-announced EPS range. Mondi remains confident in delivering "strong
& industry leading performance" but given macro uncertainty, their 2H outlook is more
cautious as they note softer demand & expect lower FV forest gains in 2H. Thus, we
trim FY19-21E EBITDA c2% (softer macro, pulp & brown sack prices). Mondi remains
a Long Term Holding in P&P, reiterate Buy on any weakness.
Solid 1H19 Results (EPS range pre-announced 23 Jul): EBITDA rose +5% to €894m
(1H18: €852m which includes IFRS16), c3% ahead of Jeff: €867m. In 1H19 Mondi
benefited from higher avg selling prices, good contribution from capex investments
(€335m Steti mill modernization), acquisitions completed in 2018 (Powerflute) and
higher FV forestry gain of €52 (1H18: €13m) that more than offset higher planned
mill maintenance costs of €80m (1H18: €55m) & cost inflation. 2Q EBITDA lower QoQ
to €423m (1Q: €471m), given €50m higher maintenance costs.
EPS rose +8% to €0.96 (c4% ahead of Jeff €0.89), in the middle of the 23 Jul-19 preannounced
EPS range of €0.93 to €0.99 (c4-11%). ROCE of 23.2% is best in class and
BS remains strong at 1.3x net debt/EBITDA (FY18: 1.3x).

11:29 am
BE11:29am

More Cautious 2019 Macro Outlook: Similar to outlook commentary from peers,
Mondi sees a softer demand environment into 2H19 given the macro uncertainties.
Prices for key paper grades are currently below the 1H avg levels (already known by
market) & following a strong FV forest gain in 1H Mondi expect a significantly lower
gain in 2H. However, their "relentless focus on continuous improvement is expected to
lessen the impact of these pressures."
Positively, with a robust business model, high-quality, cost-advantaged asset base,
and sustainable packaging solutions (note: here), Mondi are "confident of continuing
to deliver a strong and industry-leading performance."
Major capex investments: In 1H19 Mondi benefited from completed projects like
€335m Steti mill modernization & the key major capex investments, such as €340m
new kraft top white machine (Ruzomberok) are on-track. We remain supportive of
their higher ROCE internal capex. FY19-20E capex guidance of €700-800m pa is
unchanged. However, with lower global pulp prices, Mondi now expects €45m FY19E
YoY EBIT contribution from prior capex projects (vs €50m previously).

BE11:29am

Summary of Forecast Changes: We lower our FY19-21E group EBITDA c2% reflecting
softer macro, pulp & brown sack kraft paper prices while our EBIT/EPS declines c1%
given lower D&A charge. Our £20.50 PT is unchanged. Mondi remains a core longterm
holding, with best-in-sector ROCE/EBITDA margins, structurally advantaged
low cost asset base, strong BS providing financial flexibility (1.3x FY19E net debt/
EBITDA) and in our view is best placed among UK packaging stocks to benefit from
sustainability tailwinds

BE11:31am

And Davy. Not changing forecasts.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Mondi’s H1 performance was ahead of our forecasts, boosted by
a better-than-expected forestry fair value gain. Higher prices of
key products (corrugated, kraft papers, uncoated fine paper),
offset lower containerboard prices and volumes in the period. We
still expect Mondi to benefit from early signs of stabilisation in
containerboard prices in H2 (the group is still negotiating on
recent price increases). For the full year, we maintain our EBITDA
forecast of €1.7bn.

Gideon's Revenge Mondi stands to do very well in a no-deal brexit, as there will no doubt be a surge in food parcels
BE11:31am

The Fibre Packaging division (60% of group profits) reported an EBITDA of
€555m (+4% yoy). The increase resulted from higher prices (corrugated and kraft
papers) and better corrugated volumes which offset lower containerboard prices.
There was little new or incremental on recently announced price increases for
containerboard. On the conference call, management stated that it continues to
negotiate selectively on these increases. It also flagged more capacity coming in
two to three years that will require a step-up in demand to offset. The Consumer
Packaging division reported a slightly lower EBITDA yoy (-1%). As expected, the
Uncoated Fine Paper division reported a higher EBITDA due to better pricing
offsetting higher costs. The division also benefited from a gain in forestry fair
value of €52m with a much lower increase expected in H2.

BE11:31am

Is that enough containerboard for one day?

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Barclays 2Q19 operating profit was £1.584bn excluding litigation and conduct charges, inline with consensus and 4% better than MSe. Revenues were 3% better than consensus driven by £166mn capital gain from Tradeweb, otherwise inline. While costs were 8% higher, driven by BUK and CIB, giving up part of the costs discipline showed in Q1. Provisions were inline and there were no PPI charges in the quarter. TNAV was 275p, 3% better than consensus. Management maintain their 9% ROTE guidance for 2019E (MSe 8%), and costs are now expected to be below £13.6bn level due to challenging market conditions (MSe cost base is £13.4bn). The stock has been relatively strong over the last month, and with the miss on costs, we would expect some profit taking. We have an Equal-weight on Barclays which trades on 0.6x TNAV for an 8% ROTE 2020E.

BE11:36am

Revenues were £5.538bn 3/1% ahead consensus/MSe. Tradeweb capital gains accounted for £166mn, and otherwise would have been inline. Barclays UK saw a 2.5% miss in revenues, with NII down 2% qoq showing similar trends as peers. CC&P was 2.9% lower, and it was CIB that was 3% stronger underlying with banking fees showing a good recovery.Total CIB revenues were £2.8bn +8.3% yoy and 9% better than expected on a reported basis. Markets revenues were £1.4bn, 4% lower than MSe underlying, with banking fees recovering from a weak Q1 up 23% qoq. In USD FICC was down 2 yoy vs. US peers down 6% yoy, down 18% qoq. Equities were down 18% yoy in USD (US peers -6%). Costs in CIB were £1.86bn up 4.9% yoy. Considering that costs were down 9% yoy in Q1, we believe this will come as somewhat of a disappointment, but we think Barclays probably took advantage of the capital gain in the quarter, leaving more flexibility for the 2H19.CET1 was 13.4% vs. MSe of 13.2% with RWAs flat qoq. Management keeps its returns policy which will be a progressive ordinary dividend, supplemented by share buybacks. Interim dividend was 3p vs. MSe of 2.5p. MSe is or a 7.5p and £500mn share buybacks for full year 2019E.

BE11:37am

And Credit Suisse.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Sorry, not Credit Suisse. JP Morgan.

BE11:38am

Barclays' 2Q Net profit is 4% below company consensus inclusive of a
£0.2bn gain (TradeWeb) and £0.2bn higher costs which don’t change
FY’19 cost guidance, i.e. timing related. Pre-provision profit and Clean
revenues are inline with cons driven by the CIB (13% ahead of JPMe) and
FICC (+2% y/y GBP) with UK weaker. Costs were 6% above cons in Q2
but mgmt guides to a sub £13.6bn cost base for FY19 which is inline with
£13.5bn company consensus, so we expect no consensus cuts due to Q2
costs. Management also indicates positive JAWs across all business lines
in 2H with B’UK topline to improve in H2. Although P&L trends are
mixed, the key highlight within these results is the improvement in CT1 to
13.4% (+40bps q/q and above cons 13.2%) which allowed the Group to
declared a 3p interim div (vs cons 2.5p) and indicate 9p DPS for FY’19
(well above cons of 7.3p) implying a 5.8% yield FY19e. Overall, we see
Barclays as better positioned within the domestic UK banks due to
improving capital, diversification from UK Income pressures and self-help
measures which are helping drive ROTE higher towards 9%+ 2020E. With
TNAV also up to 275p (vs cons 268p), stock trades at 0.56x P/TNAV

DutchBrat Staffline / HRNet pls
BE11:39am

Q2 results vs expectations: 2Q Underlying PBT of £1.6bn was 3%
ahead of JPMe/in line with cons, and included a £166m gain on sale of
TradeWeb (TW) driven by: Total income of £5.5bn was 5%/3% ahead
of JPMe/cons (ex-TW +2% ahead of JPMe and in line with cons); Costs
of £3.5bn were 6% above JPMe/cons; Impairments of £480m were 13%
above JPMe and in line with cons. TNAV of 275p was 2%/3% ahead of
JPMe/cons and CT1 of 13.4% was +30bps/20bps ahead of JPMe/cons.
 CIB driving Group income: Total income in Barclays International of
£3.7bn (ex-TW) was 4%/2% above JPMe/cons, with CIB income of
£2.8bn 13% ahead of JPMe and Cards income of £1.1bn 1% below
JPMe. FICC had a strong performance at +2% y/y ex-TW GBP (-2% y/y
USD) driven by Credit and Securitised Products, with Equities -14% y/y
GBP (-18% y/y USD) vs strong 2Q18, Banking -1% y/y GBP (-5% y/y).

marktime Two Aussie cheats back in the hutch already
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Bored with reading that. Let me skip to the thesis.

BE11:39am

At 0.6x P/TNAV, we believe that Barclays’ strategy to return
an increasing proportion of capital generated post restructuring
and settlement of legacy litigation offers positive risk reward
for the shares. While there are challenges from Brexit-related
economic uncertainty in the UK, we believe that with most
legacy issues now in the past, the group is well placed to move
to deliver earnings accretion by actions such as redeeming
higher cost capital instruments, cost cuts and share buybacks
(as described in 4Q18 results). We rate the stock Overweight.
Our SOP-based Dec 2020 price target of 220p is calculated
using blended P/E and P/TBV for the main businesses – UK,
CIB and CCP. We assume allocated equity at 13% of RWA
and value excess capital above 13% at 1.0x.

BE11:40am

And Investec.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

We think Barclays’ Q2 2019 results offer real encouragement. The income
statement is very much in-line, with underlying profit before tax of £1.6bn just a £1m beat! However for us, the key positives are (1) strong IB performance; revenues +8% YoY, (2) 9p QoQ tNAV build to 275p, so the stock trades on an absurd 0.56x, (3) CET1 capital ratio 13.4% (INVe 13.3%, consensus 13.2%, target 13%), so we still expect a £1bn buyback in 2020e, and (4) greater than 9/10% u/l ROTE guidance for 2019/20 reaffirmed, which “demands” upgrades. BUY.

marktime And bewildered that Lloyds losing ground despite lots of buyers. Also Legal & General under 260p. Are we all being spooked by the negative Brexit rhetoric still
BE11:52am

Barclays can summarise.

BE11:53am

1H results are broadly in line, but the outlook is more robust with the group signaling organic improvement in 2H and next year, with a return to growth distinctly possible. All guidance measures have been reiterated. Exceptionals are no worse than expected and the cash flow unwind appears under control. Valuation completely ignores any recovery potential here. We are OW with a 160p price target, c40% upside potential.

· First half results are in-line with expectations and the outlook for 2020 is reiterated.

· Organic revenue decline -6.3% in 1H (vs. our -8%); with the decline in Local Gov now more skewed to 2H. Despite this organic growth is expected to improve in 2H.

· Capita reiterates plan to return to organic growth in 2020 – with core divisions starting to show signs of recovery in 2H (led by Software).

· 1H19 PBT £126m (vs. our £120m). FCF outflow of £20m in 1H (vs. £109m outflow last year); with lower deferred income outflow.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

· The orderbook is down vs FY, but post 3Q-to date wins offset that.

· FY19e PBT prior range of £265-295m reiterated. Cost savings on track [greater than £175m by end FY19e]; weighted to 2H. FY19e leverage towards upper end of 1-2x range [we have 1.7x]. FCF target reiterated (greater than £200m by FY20e).

13.1p) vs consensus £282.1m (13.2p). 2019E 1H/2H PBT split 44%/56% vs
47%/53% five-year historic average. Reiterated 2020 targets: double-digit
EBITA margin (before significant new contracts & restructuring costs) and at least

SoS 9/9 for boe
Irish HF guy @marktime, I just looked at Klepierre, Hammerson & Intu. Debt costs consume 60% of rent in INTU, 34% in Hammerson & 15% in Klepierre. Cost of debt and leverage being favourable to KL, then HMSO and INTu really in the dog house. Add to that expenses, corporation tax due to no dividends and no surprise INTU is trading at £0.46p. Hammerson net debt is okay, but rental yield to property portfolio is 4% whereas KL is 5.1%. Looking at all three, HMSO is very interesting at £2.06 but given they rejected £6.35 and NAV is now near that level, what would they sell for? £5. Simon Property & KL buy HMSO and suck up UK exposure in overall €35bn + portfolio. Buy HMSO if you like fantasy M&A and think the board will do the right thing.
12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Here's Kepler.

BE12:02pm

Not all quarters are equal at Shell. After a convincing Q1, Q2 was well
below expectations on all fronts. Q2 clean net income came in at
USD3.46bn (-26% YOY, and -35% QOQ), c. USD1.8bn or 34% below our
estimates (KECH USD5.27bn) and some 30% below consensus
(USD4.93bn). The miss is across the board (integrated gas, upstream, and
refining&trading, see earning table overleaf), despite marketing
delivering a very solid USD1.23bn clean net results (+c. 19% QOQ).
Integrated gas clean net results were down 33% QOQ (the very strong
performance from Q2 at USD2.57bn was thus not repeated with weaker
natural gas prices and LNG taking its toll, more to come on integrated gas
and LNG outlook after the conference call). In upstream, the miss is also
significant, at least USD500m versus consensus, despite Q2 production
(3,583kboe/d being broadly in line with expectations). Refining&Trading
generated a loss (-USD20m). Operating cash flow (post IFRS 16,
excluding working cap) also came some USD1.7bn below our
expectations (USD10.46bn vs. KECH USD12.16bn) down 10% YOY and
14% QOQ. Even adjusted for a negative hedging derivative impact of
USD480m in Q2, the CFFO miss is still around USD1.2bn. We have been
accustomed now for some time to volatility in Shell’s s quarterly earnings
(it was also amiss in Q2 last year followed by a convincing Q3 and Q4
release), however expect the shares to be down today.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Berenberg:

BE12:04pm

Integrated Gas was 18% below consensus, driven by weaker realised LNG and gas prices,
along with slightly lower production. The trading contribution was stable, and the company
suffered from USD0.2bn of charges related to tax provisions and other one-offs.
● Upstream missed by 15%, with weaker production sequentially, although cash flow held up
in the division. DD&A was up by USD0.4bn yoy, and the company suffered from some higher
receivable provisions in the quarter.
● Downstream missed by 25%, driven by weaker chemicals and refining margins and low
availability in the chemicals division (85% availability in the quarter, versus 93% in Q218).
The turnaround and strike in Moerdijk was partly the cause of this lower availability.
● Cash flow was USD10.5bn in the quarter, excluding working capital movements
(USD11.1bn including a working capital benefit). This included a negative USD0.3bn cash
margining impact.
● Gearing increased to 27.6% in the quarter due partly to an additional USD1.4bn of debt that
has been recognised from lease liabilities, which helped boost gearing from 26.5% at Q1.
● Overall, this was a weak set of results, hampered by a challenging macro environment. The
earnings were negatively affected by one-off impacts, which perhaps reduced earnings by
USD0.5bn. Even taking this into account we consider earnings and cash flow to be
disappointing, and note that Shell has been the best-performing of the major European oil
companies year to date. On this basis we expect the shares to be weak today.
● We value the stock based on a target 7.3x EV/DACF multiple for 2020.
